results.title: Powder
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Pictures, Caravan Pictures, Roger Birnbaum, Daniel Grodnik and Victor Salva
results.brief_description: A sci-fi film about a 16-year-old albino boy who, having spent all his life living in his grandparents basement until their passing away, suddenly finds himself in a totally foreign environment when he is removed from his home and placed into school. Jeremy Reed (Sean Patrick Flanery) nick-named Powder, has special powers but his strange physical appearance and behaviour causes division within the school and the community with bigotry and hatred on one side and respect and friendship on the other. An unusual modern day fable. Cast includes Mary Steenburgen, Lance Henriksen, Jeff Goldblum.

results.title: Powaqqatsi: Life in transformation [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Golan-Globus, Mel Lawrence, Godfrey Reggio and Lawrence Taub
results.brief_description: A feast for the eyes and ears - “Powaqqatsi: life in transformation” is a spellbinding look at life on our planet from the depths of an iron ore mine in Brazil, to the commotion of city life in the concrete jungle of Hong Kong. Featuring hypnotic music by renowned composer Philip Glass, this is a truly amazing and totally original experience in modern cinema.

results.title: Poverty, child health & child labour
results.creator_credit: DLGHS, GPN, George A. Colburn and Darrel Schwandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 21 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Explores the socioeconomic factors that have historically played a powerful role in children’s lives, and contrasts the decline in infant/child mortality and child labour in industrialised societies. Child labour in Guatemala provides one of several examples of the harsh economic circumstances in which many children still live.

results.title: Poverty and plenty
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Ronald Dick and John Howe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
The ancient greatness of he East must be preserved, say men like Nehru, “but the ancient evils must be eliminated.” This film concerns itself with the latter and shows how helping the Asiatic countries of the Commonwealth to attain higher living standards has become a challenge not only to the more privileged countries within the Commonwealth but to the nations outside. The Colombo Plan is the medium through which economic assistance is extended, and in this film we see some of the many practical forms it takes.

results.title: Poussiere D'ange = Angel Dust
results.brief_description:
Inspector Simon Blount, 34, has lost his taste for water since his wife left him for restaurant proprietor Igor. When asked by Commissaire Florimont to investigate a series of supermarket burglaries, Simon befriends angel-faced Violetta who ‘lives’ in the bedding department of a supermarket. Violetta happens to have a keen interest in Commissaire Florimont whom she suspect was involved in the murder of her mother many years ago. Film noir archetypes are evident throughout ‘Poussiere d’ange’, in the mise-en-scene, narrative voice over and characterisation as much as in the generic plot (rogue detective with morals uncovers coruption in high places). The consistently underlit or nocturnal mise-en-scene, the ubiquitous rain, and the seedy urban locations are all reminiscent of classic Hollywood film noir. But it is above all in the knowing characterisation of the detective hero that the genre is most evident. In both actions and appearance, Simon is a hyperbolic version of the crumpled private eye. He narrates his own story with the laconic humour typical of the genre. The traditional ambiguity of the film noir hero - is he a criminal or a lawman? - is epitomised in the scene where he wakes up in the drunk-tank in his own police station. His exaggeratedly dishevelled appearance - unshaven, clutching a bottle of whisky, wearing an overcoat and practically living in his beat-up car - identifies him with ‘the earlier iconography of, say, Sam Spade or Philip Marlowe.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French Cinema: an introduction’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Director, Edouard Niermans ; writers, Jacques Audiard, Didier Haudepin, Alain Le Henry, Edouard Niermans ; photography, Bernard Lutic ; music, Vincent-Marie Bouvot, Jacques Witta.
Cast: Bernard Giraudeau, Fanny Bastien, Fanny Cottencon, Jean-Pierre Sentier, Michel Aumont.

results.title: Pour la Peau D'un Flic = for a Cop's Hide
results.brief_description:
Choucas, a former cop turned private investigator, is asked by an old lady to investigate the disappearance of a young blind girl. It all seem a very mundane case. But shortly after starting the investigation, Choucas receives the visit of a very strange and nosy person. Then, later on, the old lady is murdered on her way to a meeting with Choucas.

Credits: Producer, director, Alain Delon ; writers, Alain Delon, Christopher Frank ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Oscar Benton ; art direction, Theo Meurisse.
Cast: Alain Delon, Anne Parillaud, Daniel Ceccaldi, Michel Auclair.

results.title: Pour Clemence = for Clemence
results.brief_description:
After losing his job, a 40 year old engineer decides to change the major orientation of his life and become a house husband. But this sudden change in domestic arrangements upsets his wife and daughter.

Credits: Director, Charles Belmont ; writers, Charles Belmont, Marielle Issartel ; photography, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Michel Portal, Jean Schwarz.
Cast: Jean Crubelier, Eva Darlan, Lucia Bensasson, Jacques David, Claude Debord, Jean Deschamps.
